comment.body: @ofborg buidl haskellPackages.patat

```suggestion
```

When marking a haskell-package unbroken, you have to make sure to remove this `hydraPlatforms` line as well, otherwise Hydra won't build the package.

This would happen automatically the next time we regenerated the package set, but I imagine you'd want this to happen immediately for this PR as well.

issue.title: nixos: wire up new memtest efi binary into bootloaders
issue.body:
## Issue description

Memtest finally supports EFI, so we should wire that up instead of the proprietary memtest86+ in our EFI bootloaders like GRUB and systemd-boot.

Should we leave the option to use the proprietary one?

cc @cdepillabout @K900 @LunNova

comment.body: Memtest and memtest86+ are different pieces of software, with different functionality, right?  Why would we remove the proprietary one?  I imagine that some users would want to use one or the other (or both at the same time).

issue.title: option for reversing log by default
issue.body: I find that I'm always passing `--reverse` to `gt log`, because my stacks are often big enough to scroll off the top of the screen if I don't `--reverse`.  I find that I mainly want to see the most recent comments, which tend to be at the top of the stack.  It is annoying that the thing I mainly want to see has scrolled off the top of the screen.

comment.body: @lucperkins Feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to make a call on this.

review.body:
I believe this came up on a previous purescript PR, but my understanding of the situation is:

- In nixpkgs, the top-level `purescript` derivation is not built from source, but we just `patchelf` binaries downloaded from github.
- The only binaries that are provided by the upstream purescript releases are for x86_64-linux and x86_64-darwin.
- The aarch64-darwin machines have some sort of internal emulation layer that allows them to run x86_64-darwin binaries as-is.

The question is what does `platforms` mean semantically in nixpkgs?  Does it represent the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation?  Or does it represent the platforms that the binaries can run on?

I believe the decision was that it represents the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation (so the end-user is responsible for setting up their system so that nix knows to allow both `x86_64-darwin` binaries and `aarch64-darwin` binaries).

I'm not very familiar with Darwin, so if you don't think this is how it should be, feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to weigh-in on this.

issue.title: change sink healthchecks to retry multiple times, giving time for downstream services to start

labels.name: type: feature
labels.description: A value-adding code addition that introduce new functionality.

issue.body:
### A note for the community

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment
<!-- Thank you for keeping this note for the community -->


### Use Cases

I have a simple `vector.toml` with a single `loki` sink:

```toml
...

[sinks.loki_output]
type = "loki"
inputs = ["my_transform"]  
endpoint = "http://localhost:3100"
encoding.codec = "json"
healthcheck = true
labels.bar = "{{ bar }}"
labels.foo = "{{ foo }}"
```

Sometimes when I run `vector`, `loki` isn't finished starting up.  So the healthcheck for vector's loki sink fails.

I'd like to be able to start `vector` and `loki` at the same time, and for `vector` to wait a little bit for `loki` to finish starting up, instead of just immediately giving up on the `loki` healthchecks.



### Attempted Solutions

I have just disabled the healthchecks for the loki sink, but this is not ideal.  I _do_ want the healthchecks, but I just want a little leeway before the healthchecks finally fail.

### Proposal

It would be nice if `vector` would retry the health check a few times (ideally with some sort of exponential backoff), before fully failing.

### References

_No response_

### Version

vector 0.24.1 (x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu)

issue.title: option to preserve merge commits in when doing rebase with `gt stack restack`
issue.body:
When rebasing long-running feature branches on `master`, I like to preserve merge commits, if possible.

`git rebase` has a flag for this: `-r` or `--rebase-merges`.

It would be great if `gt stack restack` gained this flag as well, so that I could preserve merge commits when rebasing a long-running feature branch.

comment.body:
My work-around for this has been to use the new [`--update-refs`](https://github.blog/2022-10-03-highlights-from-git-2-38/#rebase-dependent-branches-with-update-refs) flag on `git rebase` in order to rebase a whole stack ontop of `master` with a command like:

```console
$ git rebase --rebase-merges --update-refs origin/master
```

And then force-push all branches with

```console
$ gt stack submit
```

review.body: This LGTM, although you might want to add an example of the `nix run` command to the top of the `flake.nix` file so that people see what they can do with it.

issue.title: shortcut for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`
issue.body:
I've been using graphite for a few days.  I find myself quite frequently doing `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`.  I tend to do this whenever `master` has moved forward (due to someone on my team merging an unrelated PR), and I want to rebase my stack on the latest `master`.

Is there some shortcut I'm missing for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`?  Or am I doing something wrong that I find I frequently (at least once a day or so) want to run these commands?

issue.title: monitor the CPU hours used of nixbuild.net
issue.body:
I'd like to monitor the number of CPU hours we've used of nixbuild.net.  If we launch binplz.dev and it is really popular, we'd probably like to easily know how many CPU hours we've used, so that we can pull the plug if we end up using too much money.

My idea is to create an AWS Lambda that runs every hour or so and accesses nixbuild.net to figure out how many hours have been used so far, and then uploads the current number of hours to CloudWatch.

Then we could create an alarm on CloudWatch that will notify us if the number of hours has gone over some set amount.

comment.body: There now appears to be an HTTP API to access the CPU hours used.  Nice!

issue.title: api for getting monthly CPU hours used
issue.body:
Hi, I'd like to be able to easily monitor the number of build hours we've used so far.

I'm thinking about creating an AWS Lambda job that runs like once an hour or so, scrapes nixbuild.net's SSH [`usage`](https://docs.nixbuild.net/configuration/#account-usage) output, and uploads the results to AWS CloudWatch.  And then potentially create a CloudWatch alarm that would alert when we go over some set amount of hours.

Although I'm wondering if you have an HTTP API for querying things like CPU hours used.  I imagine that might be slightly easier for us to use.  Or alternatively if there is any other way you'd suggest for getting usage information into a monitoring solution like CloudWatch.

comment.body: Oh nice, this will be very helpful!

comment.body:
@junjihashimoto I pushed two commits.  One commit adds an `enableSixelSupport` Nix option (that is `false` by default), and another commit switches to override the top-level `vte` attribute (so that both the `termonad` and `gi-vte` library get the correct version of vte).

Could you take a look at this and tell me if it doesn't look good?

comment.body: @ofborg buidl haskellPackages.patat

```suggestion
```

When marking a haskell-package unbroken, you have to make sure to remove this `hydraPlatforms` line as well, otherwise Hydra won't build the package.

This would happen automatically the next time we regenerated the package set, but I imagine you'd want this to happen immediately for this PR as well.

issue.title: nixos: wire up new memtest efi binary into bootloaders
issue.body:
## Issue description

Memtest finally supports EFI, so we should wire that up instead of the proprietary memtest86+ in our EFI bootloaders like GRUB and systemd-boot.

Should we leave the option to use the proprietary one?

cc @cdepillabout @K900 @LunNova

comment.body: Memtest and memtest86+ are different pieces of software, with different functionality, right?  Why would we remove the proprietary one?  I imagine that some users would want to use one or the other (or both at the same time).

issue.title: option for reversing log by default
issue.body: I find that I'm always passing `--reverse` to `gt log`, because my stacks are often big enough to scroll off the top of the screen if I don't `--reverse`.  I find that I mainly want to see the most recent comments, which tend to be at the top of the stack.  It is annoying that the thing I mainly want to see has scrolled off the top of the screen.

comment.body: @lucperkins Feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to make a call on this.

review.body:
I believe this came up on a previous purescript PR, but my understanding of the situation is:

- In nixpkgs, the top-level `purescript` derivation is not built from source, but we just `patchelf` binaries downloaded from github.
- The only binaries that are provided by the upstream purescript releases are for x86_64-linux and x86_64-darwin.
- The aarch64-darwin machines have some sort of internal emulation layer that allows them to run x86_64-darwin binaries as-is.

The question is what does `platforms` mean semantically in nixpkgs?  Does it represent the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation?  Or does it represent the platforms that the binaries can run on?

I believe the decision was that it represents the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation (so the end-user is responsible for setting up their system so that nix knows to allow both `x86_64-darwin` binaries and `aarch64-darwin` binaries).

I'm not very familiar with Darwin, so if you don't think this is how it should be, feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to weigh-in on this.

issue.title: change sink healthchecks to retry multiple times, giving time for downstream services to start

labels.name: type: feature
labels.description: A value-adding code addition that introduce new functionality.

issue.body:
### A note for the community

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment
<!-- Thank you for keeping this note for the community -->


### Use Cases

I have a simple `vector.toml` with a single `loki` sink:

```toml
...

[sinks.loki_output]
type = "loki"
inputs = ["my_transform"]  
endpoint = "http://localhost:3100"
encoding.codec = "json"
healthcheck = true
labels.bar = "{{ bar }}"
labels.foo = "{{ foo }}"
```

Sometimes when I run `vector`, `loki` isn't finished starting up.  So the healthcheck for vector's loki sink fails.

I'd like to be able to start `vector` and `loki` at the same time, and for `vector` to wait a little bit for `loki` to finish starting up, instead of just immediately giving up on the `loki` healthchecks.



### Attempted Solutions

I have just disabled the healthchecks for the loki sink, but this is not ideal.  I _do_ want the healthchecks, but I just want a little leeway before the healthchecks finally fail.

### Proposal

It would be nice if `vector` would retry the health check a few times (ideally with some sort of exponential backoff), before fully failing.

### References

_No response_

### Version

vector 0.24.1 (x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu)

issue.title: option to preserve merge commits in when doing rebase with `gt stack restack`
issue.body:
When rebasing long-running feature branches on `master`, I like to preserve merge commits, if possible.

`git rebase` has a flag for this: `-r` or `--rebase-merges`.

It would be great if `gt stack restack` gained this flag as well, so that I could preserve merge commits when rebasing a long-running feature branch.

comment.body:
My work-around for this has been to use the new [`--update-refs`](https://github.blog/2022-10-03-highlights-from-git-2-38/#rebase-dependent-branches-with-update-refs) flag on `git rebase` in order to rebase a whole stack ontop of `master` with a command like:

```console
$ git rebase --rebase-merges --update-refs origin/master
```

And then force-push all branches with

```console
$ gt stack submit
```

review.body: This LGTM, although you might want to add an example of the `nix run` command to the top of the `flake.nix` file so that people see what they can do with it.

issue.title: shortcut for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`
issue.body:
I've been using graphite for a few days.  I find myself quite frequently doing `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`.  I tend to do this whenever `master` has moved forward (due to someone on my team merging an unrelated PR), and I want to rebase my stack on the latest `master`.

Is there some shortcut I'm missing for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`?  Or am I doing something wrong that I find I frequently (at least once a day or so) want to run these commands?

issue.title: monitor the CPU hours used of nixbuild.net
issue.body:
I'd like to monitor the number of CPU hours we've used of nixbuild.net.  If we launch binplz.dev and it is really popular, we'd probably like to easily know how many CPU hours we've used, so that we can pull the plug if we end up using too much money.

My idea is to create an AWS Lambda that runs every hour or so and accesses nixbuild.net to figure out how many hours have been used so far, and then uploads the current number of hours to CloudWatch.

Then we could create an alarm on CloudWatch that will notify us if the number of hours has gone over some set amount.

comment.body: There now appears to be an HTTP API to access the CPU hours used.  Nice!

issue.title: api for getting monthly CPU hours used
issue.body:
Hi, I'd like to be able to easily monitor the number of build hours we've used so far.

I'm thinking about creating an AWS Lambda job that runs like once an hour or so, scrapes nixbuild.net's SSH [`usage`](https://docs.nixbuild.net/configuration/#account-usage) output, and uploads the results to AWS CloudWatch.  And then potentially create a CloudWatch alarm that would alert when we go over some set amount of hours.

Although I'm wondering if you have an HTTP API for querying things like CPU hours used.  I imagine that might be slightly easier for us to use.  Or alternatively if there is any other way you'd suggest for getting usage information into a monitoring solution like CloudWatch.

comment.body: Oh nice, this will be very helpful!

comment.body:
@junjihashimoto I pushed two commits.  One commit adds an `enableSixelSupport` Nix option (that is `false` by default), and another commit switches to override the top-level `vte` attribute (so that both the `termonad` and `gi-vte` library get the correct version of vte).

Could you take a look at this and tell me if it doesn't look good?

comment.body: @ofborg buidl haskellPackages.patat

```suggestion
```

When marking a haskell-package unbroken, you have to make sure to remove this `hydraPlatforms` line as well, otherwise Hydra won't build the package.

This would happen automatically the next time we regenerated the package set, but I imagine you'd want this to happen immediately for this PR as well.

issue.title: nixos: wire up new memtest efi binary into bootloaders
issue.body:
## Issue description

Memtest finally supports EFI, so we should wire that up instead of the proprietary memtest86+ in our EFI bootloaders like GRUB and systemd-boot.

Should we leave the option to use the proprietary one?

cc @cdepillabout @K900 @LunNova

comment.body: Memtest and memtest86+ are different pieces of software, with different functionality, right?  Why would we remove the proprietary one?  I imagine that some users would want to use one or the other (or both at the same time).

issue.title: option for reversing log by default
issue.body: I find that I'm always passing `--reverse` to `gt log`, because my stacks are often big enough to scroll off the top of the screen if I don't `--reverse`.  I find that I mainly want to see the most recent comments, which tend to be at the top of the stack.  It is annoying that the thing I mainly want to see has scrolled off the top of the screen.

comment.body: @lucperkins Feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to make a call on this.

review.body:
I believe this came up on a previous purescript PR, but my understanding of the situation is:

- In nixpkgs, the top-level `purescript` derivation is not built from source, but we just `patchelf` binaries downloaded from github.
- The only binaries that are provided by the upstream purescript releases are for x86_64-linux and x86_64-darwin.
- The aarch64-darwin machines have some sort of internal emulation layer that allows them to run x86_64-darwin binaries as-is.

The question is what does `platforms` mean semantically in nixpkgs?  Does it represent the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation?  Or does it represent the platforms that the binaries can run on?

I believe the decision was that it represents the platforms of the binaries produced by the derivation (so the end-user is responsible for setting up their system so that nix knows to allow both `x86_64-darwin` binaries and `aarch64-darwin` binaries).

I'm not very familiar with Darwin, so if you don't think this is how it should be, feel free to ping @-NixOS/darwin to weigh-in on this.

issue.title: change sink healthchecks to retry multiple times, giving time for downstream services to start

labels.name: type: feature
labels.description: A value-adding code addition that introduce new functionality.

issue.body:
### A note for the community

<!-- Please keep this note for the community -->
* Please vote on this issue by adding a 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to the original issue to help the community and maintainers prioritize this request
* If you are interested in working on this issue or have submitted a pull request, please leave a comment
<!-- Thank you for keeping this note for the community -->


### Use Cases

I have a simple `vector.toml` with a single `loki` sink:

```toml
...

[sinks.loki_output]
type = "loki"
inputs = ["my_transform"]  
endpoint = "http://localhost:3100"
encoding.codec = "json"
healthcheck = true
labels.bar = "{{ bar }}"
labels.foo = "{{ foo }}"
```

Sometimes when I run `vector`, `loki` isn't finished starting up.  So the healthcheck for vector's loki sink fails.

I'd like to be able to start `vector` and `loki` at the same time, and for `vector` to wait a little bit for `loki` to finish starting up, instead of just immediately giving up on the `loki` healthchecks.



### Attempted Solutions

I have just disabled the healthchecks for the loki sink, but this is not ideal.  I _do_ want the healthchecks, but I just want a little leeway before the healthchecks finally fail.

### Proposal

It would be nice if `vector` would retry the health check a few times (ideally with some sort of exponential backoff), before fully failing.

### References

_No response_

### Version

vector 0.24.1 (x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu)

issue.title: option to preserve merge commits in when doing rebase with `gt stack restack`
issue.body:
When rebasing long-running feature branches on `master`, I like to preserve merge commits, if possible.

`git rebase` has a flag for this: `-r` or `--rebase-merges`.

It would be great if `gt stack restack` gained this flag as well, so that I could preserve merge commits when rebasing a long-running feature branch.

comment.body:
My work-around for this has been to use the new [`--update-refs`](https://github.blog/2022-10-03-highlights-from-git-2-38/#rebase-dependent-branches-with-update-refs) flag on `git rebase` in order to rebase a whole stack ontop of `master` with a command like:

```console
$ git rebase --rebase-merges --update-refs origin/master
```

And then force-push all branches with

```console
$ gt stack submit
```

review.body: This LGTM, although you might want to add an example of the `nix run` command to the top of the `flake.nix` file so that people see what they can do with it.

issue.title: shortcut for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`
issue.body:
I've been using graphite for a few days.  I find myself quite frequently doing `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`.  I tend to do this whenever `master` has moved forward (due to someone on my team merging an unrelated PR), and I want to rebase my stack on the latest `master`.

Is there some shortcut I'm missing for `gt repo sync --restack && gt stack submit`?  Or am I doing something wrong that I find I frequently (at least once a day or so) want to run these commands?

issue.title: monitor the CPU hours used of nixbuild.net
issue.body:
I'd like to monitor the number of CPU hours we've used of nixbuild.net.  If we launch binplz.dev and it is really popular, we'd probably like to easily know how many CPU hours we've used, so that we can pull the plug if we end up using too much money.

My idea is to create an AWS Lambda that runs every hour or so and accesses nixbuild.net to figure out how many hours have been used so far, and then uploads the current number of hours to CloudWatch.

Then we could create an alarm on CloudWatch that will notify us if the number of hours has gone over some set amount.

comment.body: There now appears to be an HTTP API to access the CPU hours used.  Nice!

issue.title: api for getting monthly CPU hours used
issue.body:
Hi, I'd like to be able to easily monitor the number of build hours we've used so far.

I'm thinking about creating an AWS Lambda job that runs like once an hour or so, scrapes nixbuild.net's SSH [`usage`](https://docs.nixbuild.net/configuration/#account-usage) output, and uploads the results to AWS CloudWatch.  And then potentially create a CloudWatch alarm that would alert when we go over some set amount of hours.

Although I'm wondering if you have an HTTP API for querying things like CPU hours used.  I imagine that might be slightly easier for us to use.  Or alternatively if there is any other way you'd suggest for getting usage information into a monitoring solution like CloudWatch.

comment.body: Oh nice, this will be very helpful!

issue.title: Bump vte to use sixel
issue.body:
This pr modifies vte of nixpkgs to enable sixel.
This is the same as the trial of @gelisam with sixel.

comment.body:
@junjihashimoto I pushed two commits.  One commit adds an `enableSixelSupport` Nix option (that is `false` by default), and another commit switches to override the top-level `vte` attribute (so that both the `termonad` and `gi-vte` library get the correct version of vte).

Could you take a look at this and tell me if it doesn't look good?
